cloud_types.name: Cirrus
cloud_types.description: Cirrus clouds are thin, wispy clouds found at high altitudes, often indicating fair weather but can also signal a change in the weather.

cloud_types.name: Cirrostratus
cloud_types.description: Cirrostratus clouds are thin, ice-crystal clouds covering the sky, often creating a halo around the sun or moon and usually indicating an approaching warm front.

cloud_types.name: Cirrocumulus
cloud_types.description: Cirrocumulus clouds are small, white patches of clouds often arranged in rows at high altitudes, resembling ripples or a mackerel sky, typically indicating fair but cold weather.

cloud_types.name: Altostratus
cloud_types.description: Altostratus clouds are gray or blue-gray clouds that often cover the entire sky at mid-altitudes, typically indicating continuous and widespread precipitation.

cloud_types.name: Altocumulus
cloud_types.description: Altocumulus clouds are white or gray clouds forming patches or layers with a wavy appearance at mid-altitudes, often indicating a change in the weather.

cloud_types.name: Stratus
cloud_types.description: Stratus clouds are low-level, uniform, grayish clouds that often cover the entire sky like a blanket, creating dull or overcast weather conditions and sometimes producing light mist or drizzle.

cloud_types.name: Stratocumulus
cloud_types.description: Stratocumulus clouds are large, dark, rounded masses often covering the entire sky at low to mid-levels, typically appearing in a lumpy, honeycomb pattern, bringing cooler and overcast weather conditions, but rarely precipitating.

cloud_types.name: Nimbostratus
cloud_types.description: Nimbostratus clouds are dark, gray, low-level clouds extending over a wide area, often associated with continuous light to moderate rainfall or snowfall, distinctly lacking in the well-defined structure and towering heights found in typical storm clouds.

cloud_types.name: Cumulus
cloud_types.description: Cumulus clouds are fluffy, cotton-like formations that develop vertically, commonly visible at low altitudes, known for their puffy, 'cauliflower' appearance, and often indicate fair weather, but can develop into larger storm systems.

cloud_types.name: Cumulonimbus
cloud_types.description: Cumulonimbus clouds are large, towering vertical clouds associated with powerful thunderstorms, identifiable by their anvil-shaped tops at high altitudes, typically leading to heavy rain, lightning, thunder, hail, and even tornadoes.
